technology.short_description: Fimir are sterile, but in secret and abhorrent rituals they may sacrifice captives to create more of their vile kind.
What the Fimir cannot create themselves they will take from the settlements of other races. And the Fimir are poor creators.
The Fimir race is cornered and dwindling. They will not waste anything and will take as much loot as they can from a victorious battle.
Fimir live in remote places and are used to long marches in order to reach villages to plunder or convoys to ambush.
Fimir are a hardy race, used to living in barren lands other races show little to no interest in. They survive wounds that would kill a man and recover remarkably fast from them.

effects.description: Attrition: -50% casualties suffered from all attrition

technology.short_description: The Fimir are constantly trying to rebuild their long fallen empire from forgotten times with slavery, cruelty and tyranny. Woe to the world should they ever succeed.
The Fimir with the highest rank rules and the lower casts follow without resistance. This is the way of the Fimir.

Most physical labour such as building is done by slaves or Shearls, the lowest cast of Fimir. Since slaves are easier to come by than new Shearls, the Fimir have become adept in catching their prey alive.
Fimir are neither creative nor skilful workers, which is why they exploit captives from other races for this purpose.
Slaves are systematically broken until they no longer have the willpower left to do anything more than working for their merciless masters.
Slaves are the basis for Fimir economy and must not be wasted. They will receive just enough food and care to avoid having them expire too quickly for there is always more work that needs to be done!

The lowest of the low, Shearls are expected to work themselves to death in peace times and throw themselves at the enemy to weaken them in war times. They are still Fimir however and their strength must not be underestimated.

effects.description: Melee attack: +4 for Shearls, Shearl Scouts, and Fimm Deathquests units
Melee defence: +4 for Shearls, Shearl Scouts, and Fimm Deathquests units

technology.short_description: Some Shearls may develop traits or skills which increase their worth to the ruler - if only bearly.

effects.description: Weapon strength: +15% for Shearl Scouts, and Fimm Deathquests units
Charge bonus: +5 for Shearl Scouts and Fimm Deathquests
Missile strength: +15% for Shearl Scouts units

technology.short_description: The Fimm are the warrior caste of the Fimir, mightier, better equipped and much less numerous than the Shearls. They are the hard core of every Fimir army.

effects.description: Upkeep: -10% for Fimm Warriors, and Fianna Fimm units
Recruitment cost: -25% for Fimm Warriors, and Fianna Fimm units

technology.short_description: The members of the warrior caste receive the best equipment the colony has to offer. This makes them much more dangerous in battle.

effects.description: Recruitment rank: +4 for Fimm Warriors, and Fianna Fimm units
Weapon strength: +20% for Fimm Warriors, and Fianna Fimm units
Armour: +15 for Fimm Warriors, and Fianna Fimm units

technology.short_description: The Matriarch of the Colony, the Meargh, will only allow the mightiest and cruellest of the Fimm to lead her armies.
Fimir make natural warriors superior to those of most races. Only their small numbers hold them back.

effects.description:
Melee attack: +10 for all Fimir units
	(all armies)

Leadership: +10 for Fimir Warrior units
	(all armies)

Melee defence: +10 for Fimir Warrior units
	(all armies)

technology.short_description: The Dirach, the mage caste of the Fimir, draw on dark magic and demonic pacts to enhance their powers.

effects.description:
Winds of Magic power reserve capacity: +5
	(all armies)

technology.short_description: Fimir who are born with the ability to wield magic have a natural talent in wielding the winds of magic and can naturally unleash simple but destructive spells against their enemies.

effects.description: Missile strength: +20% for Balefiend Apprentices units
Reload time reduction: +10% for Balefiend Apprentices units

attributes.bullet_text: This unit remains hidden while firing.
This unit can move hidden in any terrain.
If this unit can hide at its current location it will not be spotted until the enemy is very close.

technology.short_description: Fimir Balefiends only ever wield harmful magic and have terrifying destructive potential on the battlefield.

effects.description: Hero recruit rank: +4 for Fimir Balefiends

technology.short_description: Often called Fog- or Mist-Demons, the Fimir never move without the cover of magically conjured mists, protecting them from the sun and the eyes of their enemies.

effects.description:
Army ability: "Creatures of the Bog"
	(all armies)

ui_effects.localised_text: Summons a pack of Feral Bog Beasts

technology.short_description: Most Fimir may carry crude pendants and talismans which are supposed to protect them from magic. Some of them even work.
The Champions of the Fimir will never fight fair and go into battle imbued with and protected by darkest magic.

effects.description: Abilities: "Warpfireball" and "Windblast" for all Lords and Heroes
Ward save: 15% for all Lords and Heroes

technology.short_description: There is a use for even the most pathetic of swamp creatures. Even if that use is just wasting the opponents time and ammunition.

effects.description: Bonus vs. Infantry: +3 for Boglars and Hound units
Replenishment: +25% for Shearls, Shearl Scouts, and Fimm Deathquests units
Speed: +20% for Boglars, and Moor Hound units

technology.short_description: The Fimir can always rely on their daemonic allies to ambush the enemy - and on the brute strength of the Mistmors.

effects.description: Charge bonus: +15 for Swamp Daemons and Fimm Mistmors
Melee attack: +5 for Swamp Daemons, and Fimm Mistmors units
Armour: +10 for Swamp Daemons, and Fimm Mistmors units

technology.short_description: Not many Fimm have the skill and intelligence necessary to tame a bog demon, but those who do will bring swift doom to their enemies.

effects.description: Bonus vs. Infantry: +8 for Nuckelavees and Bog Beast Raiders
Charge bonus: +10 for Nuckelavees and Bog Beast Raiders
Speed: +20% for Nuckelavees, and Bog Beast Raiders units

technology.short_description: Animated by dark magic similar to Necromancy, these unliving constructs of rotten wood and unlucky souls will crush their enemies without mercy.
Many giant and ancient creatures inhabit the cursed swamps and marshes of the Fimir, creatures that they have in one way or another broken and added to their raiding hosts.

effects.description: Ward save: 15% for Bog Octopus, Fog-Shrine of Balor, and Daemonomaniacs units
Recruitment rank: +4 for Bog Octopus, Fog-Shrine of Balor, and Daemonomaniacs units
Upkeep: -20% for Bog Octopus, Fog-Shrine of Balor, and Daemonomaniacs units

technology.short_description: Through dark magic a Bog Octopus's pigmented cells can be further mutated, giving the beast a way to hide in any environment.

effects.description: Attribute: Stalk for Bog Octopus units

related_attributes.bullet_text: This unit can move hidden in any terrain.

technology.short_description: The Swamps are ruled by the Fimir.  Everyone and everything within them will be used to further their goals, one way or another.

effects.description:
Missile resistance: 20% for Boglars, Moor Hounds, Swamp Daemons, Nuckelavees, Bog Beast Raiders, and Bog Octopus units
	(all armies)

Melee attack: +15 for Boglars, Moor Hounds, Swamp Daemons, Nuckelavees, Bog Beast Raiders, and Bog Octopus units
	(all armies)
Recruitment cost: -25% for Boglars, Moor Hounds, Swamp Daemons, Nuckelavees, Bog Beast Raiders, and Bog Octopus units

technology.short_description: Kroll is a goddess in her own right, and seeks a higher place amongst the Chaos Pantheon, but first she needs devotees and fanatics to flock to her cause.

effects.description:
Leadership: +5 for Boglars, Moor Hounds, Swamp Daemons, Nuckelavees, Bog Beast Raiders and Bog Octopus units
	(all armies)

technology.short_description: Fimir are boring, their emotions dull, their potential limited...but their efforts have captured the attention of Grandfather Nurgle long enough for him to grant them a small boon for their efforts.
Slaneesh has no interest in the Fimir, but their constant and futile struggle to gain his attention amuses her. A small gift may keep them going for as long as it keeps amusing him.
Even though it didn't impress him too much, the cruelty and ferocity shown in battle grant the Fimir a blessing from Khorne.
Maybe, just maybe, there is still a role to play for the Fimir in Tzeentch's many plans...if only a minor one.

technology.onscreen_name: In the Eye of the Gods
technology.short_description: The Fimir through all their struggle have successfully drawn the gaze of the Chaos Gods once again. Will this lead them to ruin or to new glory? Either way, for now, they benefit from the dark blessings of their masters.

ui_effects.localised_text: Effect intensity increases with time spent engaged in melee.
